maml:description.maml:para: Export DRS rules and groups as JSON

This cmdlet gets the specified DRS items for the given DRS Clusters, and exports their info as JSON to the given file. These include DRS VM groups, DRS VMHost groups, DRS VM to VM rules, and DRS VM to VMHost rules.
The exported JSON is suitable (targeted) for use in the Import-DrsRule cmdlet, for recreating exported rule/group objects.
Name of rule / DRS group info to get and export. If not specified, will return all rule/group info
Cluster for which to get DRS info
Path of output file in which to put DRS info in JSON format (relative or absolute). File will be created if non-existent, or overwritten if existent
Name of rule / DRS group info to get and export. If not specified, will return all rule/group info
Cluster for which to get DRS info
Path of output file in which to put DRS info in JSON format (relative or absolute). File will be created if non-existent, or overwritten if existent

dev:remarks.maml:para: Exports the DRS group/rule information for all clusters in JSON format, stored in given file with the right-now date/time stamp in the filename.

Directory: C:\importantStuff
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 1/16/2015 11:10 PM 5520 myDrsRuleInfo_16Jan2015_2310.json

For this cluster, export the DRS rules/groups whose names are like "*grp0". The -Verbose parameter causes the cmdlet to include a verbose message about the number of rules/groups exported, and the file name to which the information was written.

VERBOSE: Exported and saved information for '4' DRS rules/groups to 'c:\temp\drsInfo_NewCluster10.json'
Directory: C:\temp
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 1/17/2015 12:08 AM 1605 drsInfo_NewCluster10.json

Here, cluster NewCluster10 has no DRS groups or rules defined, yet. So, Export-DrsRule (with the -Verbose parameter) returns a verbose message with information to that effect. No .json file is created.
VERBOSE: No DRS group/rule found for like name 'doesNotExist*' in cluster with name like 'NewCluster10'

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM groups.
This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM groups. It returns DRS VM groups that correspond to the filter criteria provided by the cmdlet parameters.

The default return type holds more information than the "raw" DRS object that vSphere uses. There is also a switch to allow for just returning said raw DRS object, quite useful for consumption by other cmdlets in this module.
Name of DRS VM Group to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM group (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterVmGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Name of DRS VM Group to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM group (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterVmGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Object with information about the given DRS VM group, or a raw vSphere object

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all DRS VM groups with name like '*VM Group 1*'
The DRS VM group with the exact name 'VM Group 1' from Cluster1 will be returned.
Returns all DRS VM groups in cluster "Cluster2"

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VMHost groups.
This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM groups. It returns DRS VM groups that correspond to the filter criteria provided by the cmdlet parameters.

The default return type holds more information than the "raw" DRS object that vSphere uses. There is also a switch to allow for just returning said raw DRS object, quite useful for consumption by other cmdlets in this module.
Name of DRS VM Group to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VMHost group (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterHostGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Name of DRS VM Group to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VMHost group (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterHostGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Object with information about the given DRS VMHost group, or a raw vSphere object

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all DRS VMHost groups with name like '*VMHost Group 1*'
The DRS VMHost group with the exact name 'VMHost Group 1' from Cluster1 will be returned.
Returns all DRS VMHost groups in cluster "Cluster2"

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM to VMHost rules.
This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM to VMHost rules. It returns a number of DRS VM to VMHost rules that correspond to the filter criteria provided by the cmdlet parameters.

The default return type holds more information than the "raw" DRS object that vSphere uses. There is also a switch to allow for just returning said raw DRS object, quite useful for consumption by other cmdlets in this module.
Name of DRS VM affinity/antiaffinity rule to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM-to-VM rule (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return DRS VM to VM rule as "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterHostGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Name of DRS VM affinity/antiaffinity rule to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM-to-VM rule (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return DRS VM to VM rule as "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterHostGroup object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Object with information about the given DRS VM to VMHost rule, or a raw vSphere object

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all DRS VM to VMHost rules with name like 'Rule 1*'
Name Cluster Enabled Mandatory VMGroupName ---- ------- ------- --------- ----------- Rule 1 Cluster1 False False VM Group 1 Rule 11 Cluster2 True True All VM
Returns all DRS VM to VMHost rules in clusters named "Cluster1" and "Cluster2"

Name Cluster Enabled Mandatory VMGroupName ---- ------- ------- --------- ----------- Rule 0 Cluster1 True False VM Group 1 Rule 1 Cluster1 False False VM Group 12 Rule 2 Cluster1 False False VM Group 31 Rule 11 Cluster2 True True All VM Rule_bak Cluster2 True False testVMGroup Rule_toDel Cluster2 False True VM Group 5

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM to VM rules.

This cmdlet retrieves the DRS VM to VM rules. It returns DRS VM to VM rules that correspond to the filter criteria provided by the cmdlet parameters. The VM to VM rules can be either affinity- or anti-affinity rules.

The default return type holds more information than the "raw" DRS object that vSphere uses. There is also a switch to allow for just returning said raw DRS object, quite useful for consumption by other cmdlets in this module.
Name of DRS VM-to-VMHost rule to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM-to-VMHost rule (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return DRS VM to VM rule as "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterVmHostRuleInfo object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Name of DRS VM-to-VMHost rule to get (or, all if no name specified)
Cluster from which to get DRS VM-to-VMHost rule (or, all clusters if no name specified)
Switch: return DRS VM to VM rule as "raw" VMware.Vim.ClusterVmHostRuleInfo object (contains less info, but useful to other functions that can consume this raw object)
Object with information about the given DRS VM to VM rule, or a raw vSphere object

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all DRS VM to VM rules with name like 'Rule 1*'
Returns all DRS VM to VM rules in Cluster2

maml:description.maml:para: Import DRS rules and groups from exported info in JSON

This cmdlet creates specified DRS items for the given DRS Clusters. The cmdlet gets the information about the items to create from the exported DRS data generated by the Export-DrsRule cmdlet. The Path parameter is to the JSON file that resutls from Export-DrsRule. The items recreated include DRS VM groups, DRS VMHost groups, DRS VM to VM rules, and DRS VM to VMHost rules. One can "overwrite" existing groups/rules with the provided -Force parameter.
Filespec of JSON file with exported DRS rule info
Name of rule/group to import, or all if no name specified
Cluster whose exported rules to import, and in which to recreate said rules. If not specified, will import rules from in the JSON file without filtering on cluster

Switch to specify that the import "overwrite" existing groups/rules of same source name in target cluster ($true), or to not import groups/rules if conflict/already existing ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group/rule. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group/rule, 1) creation of new group/rule with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Filespec of JSON file with exported DRS rule info
Name of rule/group to import, or all if no name specified
Cluster whose exported rules to import, and in which to recreate said rules. If not specified, will import rules from in the JSON file without filtering on cluster

Switch to specify that the import "overwrite" existing groups/rules of same source name in target cluster ($true), or to not import groups/rules if conflict/already existing ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group/rule. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group/rule, 1) creation of new group/rule with same name

Switch to have cmdlet report-only. This is so as to just get the informational objects from the JSON file, with no further action. The filtering of the rules/groups by the specified Name and Cluster still takes place, but then the cmdlet returns the informational objects whose details were retrieved from the given JSON file; no rule/group creation is attempted.
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the new DRS VM group
Object with information about the new DRS VMHost group
Object with information about the new DRS VM to VMHost rule
Object with information about the new DRS VM to VM rule

dev:remarks.maml:para: Imports all of the DRS rules/groups whose info is in the given JSON file. The JSON file is of objects exported from the environment via the Export-DrsRule cmdlet.

Imports the rules/groups whose name is like "*hostgr*" and whose cluster property is Cluster0. The -Cluster and -Name parameters are used here to narrow the scope of the DRS items that are imported. In this example, that was only one (1) item: a DRS VMHost group.

Just get the informational objects with name like "*hostgrp0*" from the JSON file, with no further action. The cmdlet returns the informational objects whose details were retrieved from the given JSON file; no rule/group creation is attempted.

Name : hostGrp0 Cluster : Cluster0 VMHost : esxi02,esxi03 VMHostId : {HostSystem-host-621,HostSystem-host-693} UserCreated : False Type : ClusterHostGroup
Name : TestVMHostGrp0 Cluster : Cluster0 VMHost : esxi14,esxi15,esxi16 VMHostId : {HostSystem-host-721,HostSystem-host-725,HostSystem-host-729} UserCreated : True Type : ClusterHostGroup

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet creates a new DRS VM group.
This cmdlet creates a new DRS VM group with the provided parameters.
Name of DRS VM Group to create
Cluster in which to create new group
VMs to place in new group. The VMs can be specified as strings (their names) or as VirtualMachine objects

Switch to specify to "overwrite" existing group of said name in target cluster ($true), or to not create group if conflict/already existing ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group, 1) creation of new group with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Name of DRS VM Group to create
Cluster in which to create new group
VMs to place in new group. The VMs can be specified as strings (their names) or as VirtualMachine objects

Switch to specify to "overwrite" existing group of said name in target cluster ($true), or to not create group if conflict/already existing ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group, 1) creation of new group with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the new DRS VM group

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create a new DRS VM group with the name 'My VM Group' on Cluster1. The DRS VM group will contain the VMs VM1 and VM2.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet creates a new DRS VMHost group.
This cmdlet creates a new DRS VMHost group with the provided parameters.
Name of DRS VMHost Group to create
Cluster in which to create new group
The VMHosts that shall be in the new DRS VMHostgroup. The VMHosts can be given as strings (their names) or as VMHost objects

If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group, 1) creation of new group with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Name of DRS VMHost Group to create
Cluster in which to create new group
The VMHosts that shall be in the new DRS VMHostgroup. The VMHosts can be given as strings (their names) or as VMHost objects

Switch to specify to "overwrite" existing group of said name in target cluster ($true), or to not create group if conflict/already existing ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting group. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original group, 1) creation of new group with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the new DRS VMHost group

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create a new DRS VMHost group with the name 'My ESX' on Cluster1. The DRS VMHost group will contain the VMHosts esx1 and esx2.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet creates a new DRS VM to VMHost rule.
This cmdlet creates a new DRS VM to VMHost rule with the provided parameters.
Name of the new DRS VM to VMHost rule to create
Cluster in which to create the new DRS VM to VMHost rule
A switch indicating if the new DRS VM to VMHost rule shall be enabled
Switch to specify if the new DRS VM to VMHost rule is a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule
DRS VM Group to use for new VM-to-VMHost rule
DRS VMHost Group to use for VM Group to VMHost Group affinity ("run on")
DRS VMHost Group to use for VM Group to VMHost Group antiaffinity ("not run on")

Switch to specify to "overwrite" existing rule of said name in target cluster ($true) if it exists, or to not create rule if conflict/already existing in cluster ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting rule. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original rule, 1) creation of new rule with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Name of the new DRS VM to VMHost rule to create
Cluster in which to create the new DRS VM to VMHost rule
A switch indicating if the new DRS VM to VMHost rule shall be enabled
Switch to specify if the new DRS VM to VMHost rule is a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule
DRS VM Group to use for new VM-to-VMHost rule
DRS VMHost Group to use for VM Group to VMHost Group affinity ("run on")
DRS VMHost Group to use for VM Group to VMHost Group antiaffinity ("not run on")

Switch to specify to "overwrite" existing rule of said name in target cluster ($true) if it exists, or to not create rule if conflict/already existing in cluster ($false or not specified). If $false and conflict, error thrown for each conflicting rule. "Overwrite" is accomplished by 0) removal of original rule, 1) creation of new rule with same name
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the new DRS VM to VMHost rule

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new DRS VM to VMHost rule in Cluster0. The new rule is enabled, and is a "must run on" rule. It involves the VMs in DRS VM group testVmGrp0 and the VMHosts in DRS VMHost group VMHostGrp0.
Name Cluster Enabled Mandatory VMGroupName ---- ------- ------- --------- ----------- testVmToVMHostRule0 Cluster0 True True testVmGrp0

Creates a new DRS VM to VMHost rule in Cluster0. The new rule is disabled, and is a "should not run on" rule. It involves the VMs in DRS VM group vmGrp1 and the VMHosts in DRS VMHost group VMHostGrp1.
Name Cluster Enabled Mandatory VMGroupName ---- ------- ------- --------- ----------- testVmToHostRule1 Cluster0 False False vmGrp1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create a new DRS VM to VM rule for the VM1 and VM2. The rule will be enabled. The rule expresses an obligation ("shall" or "must"). The rule will be an anti-affinity rule.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet removes a DRS VM group.
This cmdlet removes a DRS VM group that fits the provided parameters.
Name of DRS VM Group to remove
Cluster from which to remove the DRS VM group
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Name of DRS VM Group to remove
Cluster from which to remove the DRS VM group
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will remove all DRS VM groups on Cluster1, whose name starts with 'My'
To suppress confirmation, pass "-Confirm:$false" to the Remove-DrsVMGroup cmdlet.
Gets DRS VM group "testGrpToKill" from all clusters, and removes said groups. Prompts for confirmation due to the impact level. Upon answering "Y", the groups are removed.
To suppress confirmation, pass "-Confirm:$false" to the Remove-DrsVMGroup cmdlet.

Confirm Are you sure you want to perform this action? Performing the operation "Remove DRS VM group 'testGrpToKill'" on target "Cluster0". [Y] Yes [A] Yes to All [N] No [L] No to All [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): Y

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will remove the DRS VM to VMHost rule, on cluster Cluster1, whose name is exactly 'Rule1'
Gets DRS VM to Host rules "testVmToHostRule1" from all clusters, and removes said rules. Prompts for confirmation due to the impact level. Upon answering "Y", the rules are removed.
To suppress confirmation, pass "-Confirm:$false" to the Remove-DrsVMToVMHostRule cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet changes a DRS VM group.
This cmdlet changes settings of the DRS VM group with the provided parameters.
The name of the DRS VM group to modify
Cluster in which the DRS VM group resides
The VM that shall be in the DRS VM group. The VMs can be specified as strings (their names) or as VirtualMachine objects
Switch: append the given VM(s) as members of the DRS VM group ($true), or set them as the only members of the group ($false or not specified)?
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
The name of the DRS VM group to modify
Cluster in which the DRS VM group resides

Switch: append the given VM(s) as members of the DRS VM group ($true), or set them as the only members of the group ($false or not specified)?
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the updated DRS VM group

dev:remarks.maml:para: The example will add Virtual Machine VM3 to DRS VM group, whose name is 'VM Group 1', on Cluster1

If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet changes a DRS VM to VMHost rule.
This cmdlet changes a DRS VM to VMHost rule with the provided parameters.
The name of the DRS VM to VMHost rule to modify
Cluster in which DRS VM to VMHost rule resides
A switch indicating if the DRS VM to VMHost rule shall be enabled
The name of the new DRS VM group to use for this rule. This will replace the current DRS VM group in the rule
The name of the new DRS VMHost group to use for this rule. This will replace the current DRS VMHost group in the rule
A switch the allows to specify if the DRS VM to VMHost rule is to be changed to a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule.
Switch: Make this a "run on" rule. If $false (or not specified), this will be a "not run on" rule
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
The name of the DRS VM to VMHost rule to modify
Cluster in which DRS VM to VMHost rule resides
A switch indicating if the DRS VM to VMHost rule shall be enabled
The name of the new DRS VM group to use for this rule. This will replace the current DRS VM group in the rule
The name of the new DRS VMHost group to use for this rule. This will replace the current DRS VMHost group in the rule
A switch the allows to specify if the DRS VM to VMHost rule is to be changed to a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule.
Switch: Make this a "run on" rule. If $false (or not specified), this will be a "not run on" rule
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the updated DRS VM to VMHost rule

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the DRS VM to VMHost rules, whose name is 'Rule1', on Cluster1. The DRS VM group used in the rule will now be the DRS VM group named 'My VM'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Cluster Cluster0 | Get-DrsVMToVMHostRule testVmToHostRule0 | Set-DrsVMToVMHostRule -Enabled -KeepTogether:$false | Format-List *

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the given cluster and then the DRS VM to VMHost rule "testVmToHostRule0" therein, and then: enables the rule sets it as an anti-affinity rule, keeping the VMs in the DRS VM group off of the VMHosts in the DRS VMHost group

Name : testVmToHostRule0 Cluster : Cluster0 ClusterId : ClusterComputeResource-domain-c266 Enabled : True Mandatory : True VMGroupName : VmGrp0 AffineHostGroupName : AntiAffineHostGroupName : VMHostGrp0 UserCreated : True Type : ClusterVmHostRuleInfo

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet changes a DRS VM to VM rule.
This cmdlet changes a DRS VM to VM rule with the provided parameters.
The name of the DRS VM to VM rule to modify
The cluster in which the DRS VM to VM rule resides
A switch indicating if the DRS VM to VM rule shall be enabled
A switch the allows to specify if the DRS VM to VM is to be changed to a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule
Switch that indicates if the new DRS VM to VM rule is an "affinity" ($true) or "anti-affinity" ($false or not specified) VM to VM rule
The VM that shall be in the DRS VM to VM rule. The VMs can be specified as strings (their names) or as VirtualMachine objects

A switch indicating if the Virtual Machines specified on the VM parameter shall replace the current VM in the DRS VM to VM rule ($false or not specified), or if they shall be appended to the current VM in the DRS VM to VM rule ($true)
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
The name of the DRS VM to VM rule to modify
The cluster in which the DRS VM to VM rule resides
A switch indicating if the DRS VM to VM rule shall be enabled
A switch the allows to specify if the DRS VM to VM is to be changed to a "should" ($false or not specified) or a "must" ($true) rule
Switch that indicates if the new DRS VM to VM rule is an "affinity" ($true) or "anti-affinity" ($false or not specified) VM to VM rule
The VM that shall be in the DRS VM to VM rule. The VMs can be specified as strings (their names) or as VirtualMachine objects

A switch indicating if the Virtual Machines specified on the VM parameter shall replace the current VM in the DRS VM to VM rule ($false or not specified), or if they shall be appended to the current VM in the DRS VM to VM rule ($true)
Indicates that the cmdlet is run only to display the changes that would be made, and no objects are actually modified
If the value is $true, indicates that the cmdlet asks for confirmation before running. If the value is $false, the cmdlet runs without asking for user confirmation.
Object with information about the updated DRS VM to VM rule

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example disabled the VM to VM rule, whose name is 'My Rule', on Cluster1

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Cluster Cluster0 | Get-DrsVMToVMRule testVmToVmRule0 | Set-DrsVMtoVMRule -Mandatory:$false -KeepTogether -VM VM2 -Append

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the given cluster and then the DRS VM to VM rule "testVmToVmRule0 " therein, and then: makes the rule a "should" instead of a "must" rule sets it as an affinity rule, keeping the VMs in the DRS VM group together as feasible appends VM "VM2" to the list of VMs to which the rule pertains
